adjourned.heading: Hearing didn't take place
content: The hearing for your appeal didn’t take place as scheduled. We’ve sent you a letter explaining why, which you should receive by {{adjournedLetterReceivedByDate|formatDate}}.
We’ll contact you by {{hearingContactDate|formatDate}} to let you know the details of your new hearing.

appealReceived.heading: Appeal received
appealReceived.content: We’ve told DWP that you’ve appealed against their decision. They should respond before {{dwpResponseDate|formatDate}}. We’ll contact you and explain the next steps when they’ve replied.

closed.heading: Appeal closed
content: Your ESA benefit appeal is now closed.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

dormant.heading: Change of decision
content: DWP have told us they changed their decision on your entitlement to ESA in your favour. We’ve therefore closed this appeal. If you don’t agree with their new decision you can start a new appeal.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

dwpRespond.heading: DWP response
content: DWP have written a response to your ESA benefit appeal. They should have sent you a copy in the post.
We’re now in the process of booking a hearing for your appeal. We’ll contact you by {{hearingContactDate|formatDate}} with the details.

dwpRespondOverdue.heading: DWP response overdue
content: DWP were due to respond to your appeal by {{dwpResponseDate|formatDate}}. We’ve written to them again to remind them. We’ll let you know when they respond.

evidenceReceived.heading: Evidence received
evidenceReceived.content: The {{evidenceType}} evidence you sent was received by us on {{date|formatDate}}.

hearing.heading: Hearing took place
content: Your hearing took place on {{date|formatDate}}. The decision was sent to you in the post and should have arrived at your registered address by {{decisionLetterReceiveByDate|formatDate}}.
We can’t publish the decision online or tell you over the phone. This is to protect your personal information.

hearingBooked.heading: Hearing booked
hearingBooked.content: A hearing has been booked for your appeal.

lapsedRevised.heading: Change of decision
content: DWP have told us they changed their decision on your entitlement to ESA in your favour. We’ve therefore closed this appeal. If you don’t agree with their new decision you can start a new appeal.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

newHearingBooked.heading: New hearing booked
newHearingBooked.content: A new hearing has been booked for your appeal.

pastHearingBooked.heading: Still booking a hearing
pastHearingBooked.content: We’re still trying to find a suitable time for your ESA benefit appeal. We’ll contact you as soon as we’ve scheduled it. We apologise for any inconvenience this may cause you.

postponed.heading: Hearing postponed
content: The hearing for your ESA benefit appeal has been postponed and will now take place on a different day.
We’ll book a new hearing for your appeal. We’ll contact you by {{hearingContactDate|formatDate}} with the details.

withdrawn.heading: Appeal withdrawn
content: You told us you wanted to withdraw your appeal so we’ve closed it.
If you have any questions relating to your benefits, contact DWP. You can find their contact details on any correspondence you’ve received from them.

appeal.happening: Appeal received. This is the current status of your appeal
appeal.happened: Appeal received. This step is complete.

dwpRespond.due: DWP respond to your appeal. This has not happened yet.
dwpRespond.happening: DWP respond to your appeal. This is the current status of your appeal.
dwpRespond.happened: DWP respond to your appeal. This step is complete.

hearingBooked.due: Hearing booked. This has not happened yet.
hearingBooked.happening: Hearing booked. This is the current status of your appeal.
hearingBooked.happened: Hearing booked. This step is complete.

hearing.due: Hearing for your appeal. This has not happened yet.
hearing.happening: Hearing for your appeal. This is the current status of your appeal.
hearing.happened: Hearing for your appeal. This step is complete

claimExpenses.title: Claiming expenses to attend your hearing
claimExpenses.content: You may be able to claim back some of the money you spend on attending your hearing.

content: You should use public transport where possible. Keep your travel tickets and bring them with you to your hearing. You’ll be given a claim form to fill out by the tribunal clerk.

If you have a health condition or disability which means you can’t get yourself to the hearing then you might be able to claim for a taxi. You’ll need to get authorisation first by phoning 0300 123 1142.

evidence.receivedBy: All evidence should be received by 21 April 2017. This is so there’s time to read it before your hearing.

dwp.heading: DWP evidence received
dwp.content: The evidence DWP sent was received by us on 6 April 2017.

default.heading: Evidence received
default.content: The evidence was received on 6 April 2017

appellant.heading: Evidence received
appellant.content: The evidence that you sent was received by us on 6 April 2017.

tribunalsService.heading: Evidence received
tribunalsService.content: The evidence the Tribunal Service sent was received by us on 6 April 2017.

representative.heading: Evidence received
representative.content: The evidence the representative sent was received by us on 6 April 2017.

provide.title: Providing evidence to support your appeal
provide.content: Evidence is anything that supports your appeal. It could be medical records, letters or documents. What you say at the hearing is also evidence. It all helps the tribunal understand the facts of your appeal.

medicalEvidence.heading: Medical evidence
content: This is the most important form of evidence. Medical evidence helps the tribunal understand your condition and how it affects your life.

As a patient, you have a right to a copy of your medical records. You’ll need to ask your doctor for them as early as possible in your appeal. Only get records going back 2 years from the time you made your appeal.

You might have other medical evidence which isn’t included in your medical records. For example a letter from a consultant, physiotherapist or mental health worker. Submit these too, if they are relevant to your condition at the time you received your decision from DWP.

You’ll need to send evidence to the tribunal as early as possible. If you submit evidence too close to your hearing, it could be delayed to a different day because there hasn’t been enough time to review it.
Please be aware your doctor or consultant may charge you for your medical records. We can’t reimburse you for this.

oralEvidence.heading: Oral evidence
content: What you or anyone else says on your behalf at the hearing is called oral evidence. If you have a carer or someone who supports you in your home, you might want to invite them to come and tell the tribunal about your condition.
You should check the person is willing to talk at your hearing and available on the day.

whereToSendEvidence.heading: Where to send your evidence
content: Post evidence to the following address, clearly marked with your appeal reference number:
address: Liverpool Social Security and Child Support Tribunal

register.title: Register for notifications
register.content: Receive reminders and notifications to keep you updated on the progress of your appeal
register.question: How would you like to receive notifications?

manage.title: What do you want to do?
manage.visuallyHidden: What do you want to do?

stop.title: You’ll stop receiving email updates and reminders about your ESA benefit appeal.

stopConfirmation.title: You’ve stopped email notifications
stopConfirmation.content: You won’t receive any more emails about your ESA benefit appeal.

addressChange.title: Your new email address
addressChange.visuallyHidden: What do you want to do?

errors.title: There are errors on the page.

addressChangeConfirmed.title: Emails about your ESA benefit appeal will now be sent to
addressChangeConfirmed.content: We’ve sent a confirmation email to that address. Check it in a few minutes.

errors.emptyStringEmailHeadingTwo: New email address not entered again
errors.emptyStringEmailField: You have not entered your email address. Enter your email address.
errors.emptyStringEmailFieldTwo: You have not entered your email address again. Enter your email address again.
errors.noMatchField: Your email addresses don’t match. Check and enter them again.
errors.notValidField: The email address you’ve entered is invalid. Check it and enter it again.

details.title: What to expect at your hearing

expectations.title: What to expect at your hearing
expectations.link: Find out what your hearing is going to be like
expectations.content: Your hearing is where you explain your case and get a decision on your benefit appeal. The tribunal is independent from DWP and will listen to both sides of the dispute before making a decision.

whenYouArrive.heading: When you arrive
whenYouArrive.content: You’ll be greeted by a tribunal clerk. They’ll take care of you at the hearing venue and answer any questions you may have. You’ll sit in a waiting area until your hearing begins.

theHearingRoom.imageAlt: A tribunal hearing with four people, dressed informally, sat around a table.
theHearingRoom.heading: The hearing room
theHearingRoom.content: The tribunal clerk will take you into a room for your hearing. It’s more like a meeting room than a courtroom. The judge and other panel members will be sat behind a table. You’ll be invited to sit opposite them. If you have someone to support you or to give evidence, they’ll sit next to you.

peopleAtHearing.heading: The people at your hearing
content: The tribunal is made up of a panel of people who’ll make a balanced decision on your appeal.
The judge runs the hearing. They’ll explain how it works. They’ll also take notes throughout. This is to create a record of the hearing.

A doctor and a disability expert sit with the judge in Personal Independence Payment (PIP) appeals. They provide medical and disability advice. In Employment Support Allowance (ESA) appeals there’ll just be a doctor with the judge.

dwp.heading: DWP
content: A representative from DWP may be there. They are not on the panel and are there to speak on behalf of DWP . This representative won’t be the person who made the decision about your benefits.

duringHearing.heading: During your hearing
content: The judge and the other panel members will ask you some straightforward questions. They’re trying to understand how your condition affects your life. They may ask how you cope with certain tasks or about the types of of things you need help with. This takes about an hour.

Sometimes the panel will need more evidence or information to help them make a decision. It’s important that you submit all your evidence well before the hearing so they have time to review it. Otherwise they may have to postpone the hearing to a different day.

gettingDecision.heading: Getting a decision
content: After you’ve answered all the questions you’ll be asked to wait outside while the panel members discuss your appeal. You’ll then be asked back into the room to be told the decision.
The judge will explain whether you’re entitled to the benefit and if so, at what level.
Sometimes the tribunal may need more time to make a decision. If that happens the decision about your appeal will be posted to you.

hearingDetails.interpretersBookedByUs: Only interpreters booked by us can translate for you at the hearing.
hearingDetails.incorrect: If you can't attend, call us on 0300 123 1142

pleaseNote.heading: Please note
content: You can bring people to support you at your hearing. For example family, friends or a support worker. There will be a limit to the number of people you can take into the hearing room because of space.
Children are allowed in the waiting area but not in the hearing room. You’ll need to bring someone to supervise them while you’re in the hearing.
Bring all documents relating to your appeal to the hearing. For example letters or evidence we or DWP have sent you.

trackYourAppeal.title: Track your benefit appeal
trackYourAppeal.hint: You can find this on any letter you’ve received about your benefit appeal.

common.availableInAnotherLanguage: This page is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

banner.text: GOV.UK uses cookies to make the site simpler.

cookies.title: Cookie Policy
cookies.description: The ‘track your benefit appeal’ website stores small files (known as cookies), on your computer. They are used to improve your experience of using the website.

list: measure how you use the website so it can be updated and improved based on your needs
remember the notifications you’ve seen so that we don’t show them to you again
description: Cookies on the ‘track your benefit appeal’ website aren’t used to identify you personally.
You’ll normally see a message on the site before we store a cookie on your computer.

howAreTheyUsed.title: How cookies are used
howAreTheyUsed.subtitle: Measuring website usage (Google Analytics)
howAreTheyUsed.description: We use Google Analytics software to collect information about how you use GOV.UK. We do this to help make sure the site is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements, e.g.

list: how long you spend on each GOV.UK page
how you got to the track your benefit appeal site
what you click on while you’re visiting the site
description: We don’t collect or store your personal information (e.g. your name or address) so this information can’t be used to identify who you are.
We don’t allow Google to use or share our analytics data.
Google Analytics sets the following cookies:

items.name: _ga
items.purpose: This helps us count how many people visit GOV.UK by tracking if you’ve visited before

items.name: _gat
items.purpose: Used to manage the rate at which page view requests are made

items.name: _utma
items.purpose: Like _ga, this lets us know if you’ve visited before, so we can count how many of our visitors are new to GOV.UK or to a certain page

items.name: _utmb
items.purpose: This works with _utmc to calculate the average length of time you spend on GOV.UK

items.name: _utmc
items.purpose: This works with _utmb to calculate when you close your browser

items.name: _utmz
items.purpose: This tells us how you reached GOV.UK (e.g. from another website or a search engine)

items.name: analytics_next_page_call
items.purpose: This lets us know the next page you visit on GOV.UK, so we can make journeys better

items.name: govuk_contact_referrer
items.purpose: This lets us know the last page you visited before using the contact GOV.UK form

ourIntroductoryMessage.title: Our introductory message
ourIntroductoryMessage.description: You may see a pop-up welcome message when you first visit GOV.UK. We’ll store a cookie so that your computer knows you’ve seen it and knows not to show it again.

items.name: seen_cookie_message
items.purpose: Saves a message to let us know that you’ve seen our cookie message

contactUs.title: Contact us
contactUs.description: For help and support with your appeal call:

error500.title: Page could not be found
error500.heading: Sorry, we're experiencing technical difficulties
content: Please try again in a few minutes.
Or, if you want an update on your appeal you can call 0300 123 1142.

error404.title: We're experiencing technical difficulties
error404.heading: Sorry, this page could not be found
content: Check that you’ve entered the correct web address.
If you want an update on your appeal you can call 0300 123 1142.
